hypothesis_content.title: News Catalyst Amplification via Liquidity Gaps
hypothesis_content.statement: During NEUTRAL/BEAR regimes, significant negative news catalysts (exchange issues, regulatory announcements) occurring during Asian trading hours (00:00-08:00 UTC) trigger 30-50% larger sell-offs than identical news during US hours, due to thinner liquidity and concentrated Asian retail selling.
hypothesis_content.rationale: Asian trading hours feature ~40% lower liquidity than US hours. Negative news triggers disproportionate selling from retail-heavy Asian markets, with fewer institutional buyers to absorb flow. Current market sensitivity to negative headlines amplifies this effect.
entry_conditions: Significant negative crypto news (Bloomberg/CoinDesk headline score >7/10)

exit_conditions.take_profit: 6% decline from entry OR volume normalizes to <150% of average
exit_conditions.time_exit: 4 hours post-entry OR US market open (14:30 UTC)

hypothesis_content.falsification_criteria: Asian-hour news events produce equal or smaller moves than US-hour equivalents, or liquidity metrics show no significant difference between sessions.
